'''William Harrison Withers Jr.''' (July 4, 1938 – March 30, 2020) was an American singer-songwriter and musician.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Still Bill (2009) A Singer Who Stopped His Showing Off|first=Mike|last=Hale|date=January 26, 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/27/movies/27still.html}}</ref> He had several hits over a career spanning 18 years, including "[[Ain't No Sunshine]]" (1971), "[[Grandma's Hands]]" (1971), "[[Use Me (Bill Withers song)|Use Me]]" (1972), "[[Lean on Me (song)|Lean on Me]]" (1972), "[[Lovely Day]]" (1977) and "[[Just the Two of Us (Grover Washington Jr. song)|Just the Two of Us]]" (1981). Withers won three [[Grammy Awards]] and was nominated for six more. His life was the subject of the 2009 documentary film ''[[Still Bill (film)|Still Bill]]''.<ref name=NYT/> Withers was inducted into the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] in 2005 and [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] in 2015.<ref name="RRHF">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/green-day-lou-reed-joan-jett-ringo-starr-lead-2015-rock-and-roll-hall-of-fame-20141216|title=Green Day, Lou Reed, Joan Jett, Ringo Starr Lead 2015 Rock and Roll Hall of Fame |last= Greene |first= Andy |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=December 16, 2014|access-date=December 16, 2014}}</ref><ref name="nyt">{{cite news |last1= Genzlinger|first1=Neil|last2=Taylor|first2=Derrick Bryson|date=April 3, 2020|title=Bill Withers, Who Sang 'Lean on Me' and 'Ain't No Sunshine,' Dies at 81|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/03/arts/music/bill-withers-dead.html| access-date=April 3, 2020}}</ref> Two of his songs were inducted into the [[Grammy Hall of Fame]].<ref name="billboard.com">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/awards/9350737/bill-withers-set-this-grammy-record-in-1988-and-it-took-25-years-to-break |title=Bill Withers Set This Grammy Record in 1988 -- And It Took More Than 25 Years to Break |first=Paul |last=Grein |date=April 3, 2020 |magazine=Billboard |access-date=January 29, 2021}}</ref>

==Early life==
Withers, the youngest of six children, was born in the small coal-mining town of [[Slab Fork, West Virginia]], on July 4, 1938.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/bill-withers-mn0000078044/biography|title=Bill Withers - Biography & History - |website=AllMusic|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref><ref name="bsisario091815">{{cite news| first= Ben |last= Sisario| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/20/arts/music/bill-withers-still-himself-but-hell-allow-the-attention.html?_r=0 |title= Bill Withers: Still Himself, but He'll Allow the Attention| work= The New York Times |date= September 18, 2015}}</ref> He was the son of Mattie (née Galloway), a maid, and William Withers, a [[mining|miner]].<ref name=nyt/> He was born with a stutter and later said he had a hard time fitting in.<ref name="rollingstone1"/> His parents divorced when he was three, and he was raised by his mother's family in nearby [[Beckley, West Virginia|Beckley]], West Virginia.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.fox19.com/2020/04/03/lean-me-lovely-day-singer-bill-withers-dies/ |title='Lean On Me,' 'Lovely Day' singer Bill Withers dies at 81|date=April 30, 2020 |website= fox19.com|access-date=May 20, 2020}}</ref> He was 13 years old when his father died.<ref name="rollingstone1"/> Withers enlisted in the [[United States Navy]] at the age of 17,<ref name=Kennedy>{{cite news| first= Mark |last= Kennedy| url= https://apnews.com/e19138ee60f29a319e45bcfba3e39331 |title= 'Lean On Me,' 'Lovely Day' singer Bill Withers dies at 81| publisher= Associated Press |website= apnews.com| date= April 3, 2020}}</ref> and served for nine years, during which time he became interested in singing and writing songs.<ref name="telegraph1"/>

==Career==
He left the Navy in 1965, relocating to Los Angeles in 1967 to start a music career.<ref name="rollingstone1"/><ref name=Kennedy/>  His debut release was "Three Nights and a Morning" in 1967.  Arranged by [[Mort Garson]], the song went unnoticed at the time but was later reworked by Withers as the track "Harlem".<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.trunkworthy.com/the-lost-bill-withers-go-go-soul-freakout-you-need-to-hear/ |first= David |last= Gorman| title= The Lost Bill Withers Go-Go Soul Freakout You Need To Hear| website= Trunkworthy.com| access-date= 26 October 2020}}</ref>

Withers worked as an assembler for several different companies, including [[Douglas Aircraft Corporation]], [[IBM]] and [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]],<ref name= RSE /> while recording [[demo (music)|demo tapes]] with his own money, shopping them around and performing in [[nightclub|clubs]] at night. When he returned with the song "[[Ain't No Sunshine]]" in 1971, he refused to resign from his job because he believed the music business was a fickle industry.<ref name="rollingstone1"/>

===Music career===
Withers continued to work on his musicianship, learning guitar.<ref name= RSE />

====Sussex Records====
[[File:Bill Withers - Just As I Am, 1971 (cropped).jpg|alt=Withers smiling and leaning in front of a brick wall|thumb|Withers in a 1971 ad for ''[[Just as I Am (Bill Withers album)|Just as I Am]]'']]
In early 1970, Withers's demonstration tape was auditioned favorably by [[Clarence Avant]], owner of [[Sussex Records]]. Avant signed Withers to a record deal and assigned former [[Stax Records]] stalwart [[Booker T. Jones]] to produce Withers's first album.<ref name="rollingstone1"/> Four three-hour [[recording sessions]] were planned for the album, but funding caused the album to be recorded in three sessions with a six-month break between the second and final sessions. ''[[Just as I Am (Bill Withers album)|Just as I Am]]'' was released in 1971 with the tracks, "Ain't No Sunshine" and "[[Grandma's Hands]]" as singles. The album features [[Stephen Stills]] playing lead guitar.<ref name="billboard.com2">{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=bill withers|bio=true}} |title=Bill Withers biography |magazine=Billboard |access-date=January 12, 2011}}</ref> On the cover of the album, Withers is pictured at his job at [[Weber Aircraft]] in [[Burbank, California]], holding his lunch box.<ref name="bsisario091815"/>

The album was a success, and Withers began touring with a band assembled from members of the [[Charles Wright & the Watts 103rd Street Rhythm Band|Watts 103rd Street Rhythm Band]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Mojo Collection: 4th Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AVQbF9lTBwgC&pg=PA244|year=2007|publisher=Canongate Books|isbn=978-1-84767-643-6|page=244}}</ref> Withers won a [[Grammy Award for Best R&B Song]] for "[[Ain't No Sunshine]]" at the [[14th Annual Grammy Awards]] in 1972. The track had already sold over one million copies and was awarded a [[music recording sales certification|gold disc]] by the [[RIAA]] in September 1971.<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs">{{cite book
| first= Joseph
| last= Murrells
| year= 1974
| title= The Book of Golden Discs
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= [[Barrie and Jenkins]]
| location= London
| pages= [https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/306 306 & 322]
| isbn= 0-214-20512-6
| url-access= registration
| url= https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/306
}}</ref>

During a hiatus from touring, Withers recorded his second album, ''[[Still Bill]]''. The single, "[[Lean on Me (song)|Lean on Me]]" went to number one the week of July 8, 1972. It was Withers's second gold single with confirmed sales in excess of three million.<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs"/> His follow-up, "[[Use Me (Bill Withers song)|Use Me]]," released in August 1972, became his third million-seller, with the [[Recording Industry Association of America|R.I.A.A.]] gold disc award taking place on October 12, 1972.<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs"/> His performance at [[Carnegie Hall]] on October 6, 1972, was recorded, and released as the live album ''Bill Withers, Live at Carnegie Hall'' on November 30, 1972. In 1974, Withers recorded the album ''[[+'Justments]].'' Due to a legal dispute with the Sussex company, Withers was unable to record for some time thereafter.<ref>{{cite book|title=Contemporary Musicians|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ego5AQAAIAAJ|year=2006|publisher=Gale Research, Incorporated|isbn=978-0-7876-8067-1|page=212}}</ref>

{{quote box|quote=Withers sang for a black nouveau middle class that didn't yet understand how precarious its status was. Warm, raunchy, secular, ''common'', he never strove for [[Ashford & Simpson]]-style sophistication, which hardly rendered him immune to the temptations of [[nouveau riche|sudden wealth]]—cross-class attraction is what gives '[[Use Me (Bill Withers song)|Use Me]]' its kick. He didn't accept that there had to be winners and losers, that fellowship was a luxury the newly successful couldn't afford. Soon sudden wealth took its toll on him while economic [[wikt:clampdown|clampdown]] took its toll on his social context.|source=—[[Robert Christgau]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Christgau|first=Robert|author-link=Robert Christgau|date=December 28, 1999|url=https://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/cg/cgv1299-99.php|title=Consumer Guide|newspaper=[[The Village Voice]]|access-date=May 2, 2019}}</ref>|align=right|style=padding:8px;|width=42%|border=1px}}
During this time, he wrote and produced two songs on the [[Gladys Knight & the Pips]] album ''[[I Feel a Song]]'', and in October 1974 performed in concert together with [[James Brown]], [[Etta James]], and [[B.B. King]] in [[Zaire]] four weeks prior to the historic [[The Rumble in the Jungle|Rumble in the Jungle]] fight between [[George Foreman]] and [[Muhammad Ali]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.billwithersmusic.com/htmlWork/bio1.html |title=Bill Withers' web site |website=Billwithersmusic.com |date=July 8, 1972 |access-date= January 12, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110829182422/http://www.billwithersmusic.com/htmlWork/bio1.html |archive-date=August 29, 2011}}</ref> Footage of his performance was included in the 1996 documentary film ''[[When We Were Kings]]'', and he is heard on the accompanying soundtrack. Other footage of his performance is included in the 2008 documentary film ''[[Soul Power (film)|Soul Power]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last= James|first=David E.|title=Rock 'n' Film: Cinema's Dance with Popular Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yjskDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA445|year=2017|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford |isbn=978-0-19-084201-7|page=445 | via= Google Books}}</ref>

====Columbia Records====
After Sussex Records folded, Withers signed with [[Columbia Records]] in 1975.<ref name= RSE>{{cite encyclopedia| title= Bill Withers |last1= Rees |first1= Dafydd |last2= Crampton |first2= Luke| encyclopedia= Rock Stars Encyclopedia |url= https://archive.org/details/rockstarsencyclo00rees|url-access= registration |page= 1079|year=1999|publisher=DK Publishing |location= London|isbn=978-0-7894-4613-8}}</ref> His first album release with the label, ''[[Making Music (Bill Withers album)|Making Music]]'', included the single "She's Lonely", which was featured in the film ''[[Looking for Mr. Goodbar (film)|Looking for Mr. Goodbar]]'' along with "She Wants to (Get on Down)". During the next three years he released an album each year with ''[[Naked & Warm]]'' (1976), ''[[Menagerie (album)|Menagerie]]'' (1977; containing the successful "[[Lovely Day]]"), and ''[['Bout Love]]'' (1978).<ref>{{cite web |title=Bill Withers |url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/59249-Bill-Withers |website=Discogs |access-date=April 3, 2020}}</ref>

Due to problems with Columbia and being unable to get songs approved for his album, he decided to focus on joint projects from 1977 to 1985, including "[[Just the Two of Us (Grover Washington Jr. song)|Just the Two of Us]]", with [[jazz]] saxophonist [[Grover Washington Jr.]], which was released during June 1980.<ref name="sun-sentinel1985">{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1985-10-27/features/8502170471_1_album-tour-record |title=Bill Withers, 'Lean On Me' Attitude Back The 47-year-old Singer, Whose Style And Delivery Fall Somewhere Between Lou Rawls And Marvin Gaye, Has Released A New Album And Embarked On A Concert Tour |work= sun-sentinel.com |date=October 27, 1985 |access-date=August 26, 2015}}</ref> The song won the [[Grammy Award for Best R&B Song]].<ref name =grammy>{{cite web |title=Bill Withers |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/bill-withers |website= grammy.com |language=en |date= November 19, 2019}}</ref> Withers next released "Soul Shadows" with [[The Crusaders (Houston group)|the Crusaders]], and "In the Name of Love" with [[Ralph MacDonald]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Bill Withers |url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/59249-Bill-Withers?sort=year%2Casc&limit=500&filter_anv=0&subtype=Singles-EPs&type=Releases&page=1 |website=Discogs.com |access-date=April 3, 2020 |language=en}}</ref> the latter being nominated for a Grammy for vocal performance.<ref name=grammy />

In 1982, Withers was a featured vocalist on the album ''Dreams in Stone'' by French singer [[Michel Berger]]. This record included one composition co-written and sung by Withers,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Michel-Berger-Dreams-In-Stone/release/1983025 |title=Michel Berger - Dreams In Stone (Vinyl, LP, Album) |publisher=Discogs.com |access-date=August 26, 2015}}</ref> an upbeat [[disco]] song about New York City titled "Apple Pie."<ref>{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://lescharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Michel+Berger&titel=Apple+Pie&cat=s |title=Michel Berger - Apple Pie |publisher=lescharts.com |access-date=August 26, 2015}}</ref>

In 1985 came ''[[Watching You, Watching Me]]'', which featured the [[Top 40]]-rated [[R&B]] single ''Oh Yeah!'' and ended Withers's business association with Columbia Records. Withers stated in interviews that a lot of the songs approved for the album, in particular, two of the first three singles released, were the same songs that had been rejected in 1982, hence contributing significantly to the eight-year hiatus between albums.<ref name="sun-sentinel1985"/> Withers also stated it was frustrating seeing his record label release an album for [[Mr. T]], an actor, when they were preventing him, an actual singer, from releasing his own. He toured with [[Jennifer Holliday]] in 1985 to promote what would be his final studio album.<ref name="sun-sentinel1985"/>

His disdain for Columbia's [[Artists and repertoire|A&R executives]] or "blaxperts", as he termed them, trying to exert control over how he should sound if he wanted to sell more albums, played a part in his decision to not record or re-sign to a record label after 1985, effectively ending his performing career, even though remixes of his previously recorded music were released well after his "retirement."<ref name="rollingstone1">{{cite magazine|last=Greene |first=Andy |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/bill-withers-the-soul-man-who-walked-away-20150414 |title=Bill Withers: The Soul Man Who Walked Away |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=April 14, 2015 |access-date=August 26, 2015}}</ref><ref name="telegraph1">{{cite news|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/7928784/Bill-Withers-interview.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220111/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/7928784/Bill-Withers-interview.html |archive-date=January 11, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |title=Bill Withers interview |work= The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=August 10, 2010 |access-date=August 26, 2015}}{{cbignore}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.songfacts.com/blog/writing/still_bill_the_story_of_bill_withers/ |title=Still Bill: The Story of Bill Withers |website= Songfacts.com |access-date=August 26, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=7236327 |title=Songwriter Bill Withers And A Career Cut Short |publisher=NPR |date=February 7, 2007 |access-date=August 26, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Frere-Jones |first=Sasha |date=March 8, 2010 |title=As Is |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2010/03/08/as-is-2 |access-date=August 26, 2015 |magazine=The New Yorker}}</ref> Finding musical success later in life than most, at 32, he said he was socialized as a "regular guy" who had a life before the music, so he did not feel an inherent need to keep recording once he fell out of love with the industry.<ref name="rollingstone1"/> After he left the music industry he said that he did not miss touring and performing live and did not regret leaving music behind.<ref name="rollingstone1"/><ref name="telegraph1"/>

====Post-Columbia career====
In 1988, a new version of "Lovely Day" from the 1977 ''Menagerie'' album, entitled "Lovely Day (Sunshine Mix)" and remixed by [[Ben Liebrand]] was released. The original release had reached number 7 in the UK in early 1978, and the re-release climbed higher to number 4.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bill Withers |url=https://www.officialcharts.com/artist/14670/bill-withers/ |publisher=The Official UK Charts Company |access-date=April 3, 2020}}</ref>

At the [[30th Annual Grammy Awards]] in 1988, Withers won the [[Grammy Award for Best R&B Song|Grammy for Best Rhythm and Blues Song]] as songwriter for the re-recording of "Lean on Me" by [[Club Nouveau]]. This was Withers's ninth Grammy nomination and third win.<ref name=Kennedy/> Withers contributed two songs to [[Jimmy Buffett]]'s 2004 release ''[[License to Chill]]''. Following the reissues of ''Still Bill'' on January 28, 2003, and ''Just As I Am'' on March 8, 2005, there was speculation of previously unreleased material being issued as a new album.<ref>Mitchell, Gail (October 14, 2005). "[http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/61070/withers-in-no-hurry-to-make-new-album Withers In No Hurry To Make New Album]". ''Billboard''.</ref> In 2006, [[Sony Music]] gave Withers’s previously released tapes back to him.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Greene |first1=Andy |title=10 Things We Learned Spending Two Days With Bill Withers |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/10-things-we-learned-spending-two-days-with-bill-withers-198985/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=April 3, 2020 |date=March 27, 2015}}</ref> In 2007, "Lean on Me" was inducted into the [[Grammy Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web |title=GRAMMY Hall Of Fame |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/awards/hall-of-fame#l |website=GRAMMY.com |access-date=April 3, 2020 |date=October 18, 2010}}</ref>

At the [[56th Annual Grammy Awards]] in 2014, ''Bill Withers: The Complete Sussex & Columbia Albums Collection'', a nine-disc set featuring Withers's eight studio albums, as well as his live album ''[[Live at Carnegie Hall (Bill Withers album)|Live at Carnegie Hall]]'', received the [[Grammy Award for Best Historical Album]] (sharing the award with the Rolling Stones' ''[[Charlie Is My Darling (film)|Charlie Is My Darling – Ireland 1965]]''). The award was presented to Leo Sacks, who produced the collection, and the mastering engineers, Mark Wilder, Joseph M. Palmaccio, and Tom Ruff.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/events/grammys-2014/5885341/grammy-awards-full-winners-list-2014-complete|title=56th GRAMMY Awards: Full Winners List|magazine=Billboard|access-date=April 3, 2019}}</ref>
[[File:Bill Withers at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame 02.jpg|alt=Withers standing before a small crowd in a suit|thumb|Withers at the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] in 2015]]
In 2005, Withers was inducted into the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]].<ref name=Kennedy/> In April 2015, he was inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] by [[Stevie Wonder]]. He described the honor as "an award of attrition" and said: "What few songs I wrote during my brief career, there ain't a genre that somebody didn't record them in. I'm not a virtuoso, but I was able to write songs that people could identify with. I don't think I've done bad for a guy from Slab Fork, West Virginia."<ref name="rollingstone1"/><ref>{{cite news |last1= Smith|first1=Troy L.|title=Bill Withers, Stevie Wonder charm during their 2015 Rock and Roll Hall of Fame speeches |url= http://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2015/04/bill_withers_stevie_wonder_cha.html|access-date=October 1, 2015|newspaper= [[The Plain Dealer]] |date=April 19, 2015}}</ref> Later that year, a tribute concert in his honor was held at Carnegie Hall featuring [[Aloe Blacc]], [[Ed Sheeran]], [[Dr. John]], [[Michael McDonald (singer)|Michael McDonald]], and [[Anthony Hamilton (musician)|Anthony Hamilton]]. The concert recreated Withers's 1973 concert album, ''Live at Carnegie Hall'', along with some of his other material. Withers was in attendance and spoke briefly onstage.<ref>{{cite web| first= Ben |last= Sisario| url= http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/03/a-tribute-to-bill-withers-at-carnegie-hall/ |title= A Tribute to Bill Withers at Carnegie Hall| work= The New York Times| date= August 3, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| first= Jon |last= Pareles| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/03/arts/music/review-a-bill-withers-tribute-with-his-soul-disciples.html?_r=0 |title= Review: A Bill Withers Tribute With His Soul Disciples| work= The New York Times| date= October 2, 2015}}</ref>

In February 2017, he made an appearance on [[Joy Reid]]'s [[MSNBC]] show to talk about the refugee crisis as well as the political climate in America.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bill Withers talks the Grammys and politics |url=https://www.msnbc.com/am-joy/watch/bill-withers-talks-the-grammys-and-politics-875598403874 |work=MSNBC |date=February 12, 2017|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref>

==Legacy==
Withers was known for his "smooth" [[baritone]] vocals and "sumptuous" soul arrangements.<ref name="bbc"/> He wrote some of the most covered songs of the 1970s, including "Lean on Me" and "Ain't No Sunshine".<ref name="nyt" /> The former entered the [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]] chart through multiple versions, including [[Club Nouveau]]'s [[Lean on Me (song)#Club Nouveau version|1987 cover]], which made the composition one of nine songs to have led the chart via different acts.<ref name="bb">{{Cite magazine| url= https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/chart-beat/9350616/bill-withers-biggest-billboard-hits |title= 'Lean On Me,' 'Use Me,' 'Just the Two of Us' & More: Bill Withers' Biggest Billboard Hits |magazine=Billboard| first= Xander| last= Zellner| date= April 3, 2020 | access-date= November 17, 2020}}</ref> With "Lovely Day", he set the record for the longest sustained note on a chart hit on American charts, holding a high [[E (musical note)|E]] for 18 seconds.<ref name="bbc"/> Editors from ''[[The Guardian]]'' considered that Withers's songs are "some of the most beloved in the American songbook," citing, "'Ain't No Sunshine' is regarded as one of the all-time great breakup tracks, while 'Lean on Me', an ode to the supportive power of friendship{{nbsp}}..."<ref>{{Cite news| url= https://www.theguardian.com/music/2020/apr/03/bill-withers-influential-soul-singer-dies-aged-81|title=Bill Withers, influential soul singer behind Ain't No Sunshine, dies aged 81 |work= The Guardian | date= April 3, 2020| first1= Tim |last1= Jonze |first2= Ben |last2= Beaumont-Thomas| access-date= November 17, 2020}}</ref> For the same newspaper, [[Alex Petridis]] noticed "[he] laid pain and paranoia under his deceptively gentle songs, and retired early having conquered gospel, funk, blues, disco and more."<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/music/2020/apr/03/bill-withers-the-brilliant-folk-soul-star-who-said-it-all-with-time-to-spare|title=Bill Withers: the brilliant folk-soul star who said it all with time to spare| work= The Guardian | author-link= Alexis Petridis| first= Alexis| last= Petridis| date= April 3, 2020 | access-date= November 17, 2020}}</ref> In ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', writer Andy Greene noted that several of his songs "are embedded in the culture and have been covered countless times."<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/bill-withers-obituary-977929/|title=Bill Withers, Hall of Fame Soul Singer, Dead at 81| magazine= Rolling Stone |date= April 3, 2020 | access-date= November 17, 2020 | last=Greene|first=Andy}}</ref>

Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', Giovanni Russonello considered Withers "[a] soulful singer with a gift for writing understated classics", adding, "the ultimate homespun hitmaker, he had an innate sense of what might make a song memorable, and little interest in excess attitude or accoutrements. Ultimately Withers reminded us that it’s the everyday that is the most meaningful: work, family, love, loss."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/04/arts/music/bill-withers-songs.html|title=Bill Withers's 10 Overlooked Songs| work= The New York Times | first= Giovanni |last= Russonello| date= April 4, 2020| access-date= November 17, 2020}}</ref> A ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' article considered that Withers "stands as one of R&B/soul music's most revered singer-songwriters."<ref name="bb"/> In the same magazine, writer Gail Mitchell acknowledged "Withers' legacy has flourished in the decades since, thanks to a cross-section of artists who have covered/sampled his songs or cited him as a major influence."<ref>{{Cite magazine |url= https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7461878/bill-withers-death|title=Bill Withers, 'Lean On Me' and 'Lovely Day' Singer, Dies at 81| first= Gail| last= Mitchell| magazine=Billboard| date= April 3, 2020| access-date= November 17, 2020}}</ref> Musician and music journalist [[Questlove]] referred to Withers's post-breakup 1974 album ''[[+'Justments]]'' as "a diary [...] [it] was a pre-[[reality show|reality-show]] look at his life. Keep in mind this was years before [[Marvin Gaye]] did it with ''[[Here, My Dear]]''."<ref name= "rollingstone1"/> The [[Beach Boys]]' [[Brian Wilson]] deemed him "a songwriter's songwriter".<ref name="bbc">{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-52155227 |title=Bill Withers, 'Lean On Me' and 'Lovely Day' Singer, Dies at 81 |date=April 3, 2020 |work=[[BBC News]] |access-date=November 17, 2020}}</ref> Musicians [[Sade (singer)|Sade]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sade.com/biography |title=Sade Biography |publisher= Sade| website= Sade.com}}</ref> [[D'Angelo]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/09/30/dangelo-cancels-performance-at-bill-withers-tribute-show/ |title= D'Angelo Cancels Performance at Bill Withers Tribute Show| work= The New York Times |first=Ben |last=Sisario |date=September 30, 2015 |access-date=November 17, 2020}}</ref> [[Justin Timberlake]],<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/justin-timberlake-bill-withers-tribute-978501/|title=Justin Timberlake Pays Tribute to Bill Withers: 'One of My Biggest Idols'| first= Daniel| last= Kreps |date=April 4, 2020 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=November 17, 2020}}</ref> [[John Legend]]<ref>{{Cite magazine |url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/john-legend-on-singing-with-bill-withers-at-rock-hall-dont-f-k-it-up-46731/ |title=John Legend on Singing with Bill Withers at Rock Hall: 'Don't F–k It Up' |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=April 20, 2015 |first=Andy |last=Downing |access-date= November 17, 2020}}</ref> and [[Ed Sheeran]]<ref name= "bsisario091815"/> have credited Withers as a music inspiration.

==Personal life and death==
[[File:Bill Withers tribute concert (2008-08-09) - Bill Withers and Kori Withers 3163.jpg|alt=Bill onstage hugging his daughter and speaking into a microphone|thumb|Withers with his daughter Kori at a 2008 tribute concert]]
Withers married actress [[Denise Nicholas]] in 1973 during her stint on the sitcom ''[[Room 222]]''.<ref name="rollingstone1" /> They divorced in 1974.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=May 2, 1974 |title= Divorce Action Splits Singer Bill Withers, Actress Denise Nicholas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uI8DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA15 |journal= Jet|volume= 46| issue =  6|pages=15}}</ref>

In 1976, Withers married Marcia Johnson. They had two children, Todd and Kori.<ref name="rollingstone1" /> Marcia eventually assumed the direct management of his publishing companies, in which his children also became involved as they became adults.<ref>Elsworth, Catherine (October 8, 2006). "[https://web.archive.org/web/20080214221758/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2006/08/10/bmbill10.xml Still A Lovely Day]". ''The Telegraph''.</ref>

Withers died from heart complications in a Los Angeles hospital on March 30, 2020, at age 81; his family announced his death four days later.<ref>{{cite news|date=April 4, 2020|title=Lean On Me singer Bill Withers dies at 81|work=[[BBC News]]|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-52155227|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200403145040/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-52155227|archive-date=April 3, 2020|mode=cs2}}; {{cite news|title=Bill Withers, 'Lean On Me,' 'Ain't No Sunshine' singer, dies at 81|work=[[WSOC-TV]]|url=https://www.wsoctv.com/news/trending/bill-withers-lean-me-aint-no-sunshine-singer-dies-81/7WXSYRTPARB5PBAMHOYAJYKEOI/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Genzlinger|first=Neil|date=2020-04-03|title=Bill Withers, Who Sang 'Lean on Me' and 'Ain't No Sunshine,' Dies at 81|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/03/arts/music/bill-withers-dead.html|access-date=2021-08-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201208202745/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/03/arts/music/bill-withers-dead.html|archive-date=2020-12-08|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> He is interred in the [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.tmz.com/2020/04/28/bill-withers-cause-of-death-certificate-cardiopulmonary-arrest-heart/|title=Bill Withers Died of Cardiopulmonary Arrest, Underlying Heart and Lung Issues| work=TMZ.com |date=April 28, 2020}}</ref>
